text:
Washington Street, at the S.E. corner of Johnson Street, showing Haverly's Theatre. This building replaced the former Brooklyn Theatre, which was destroyed by fire on December 5, 1876, and in which 300 people lost their lives, because of an inadvertent act on the part of the firemen in closing the doors before the building was emptied. Because of the furore resulting, when this building was erected it was considered the best in the United States from both a theatrical and safety standpoint. It was demolished in 1891, to make way for the new "Brooklyn Eagle" Building. In 1868, St. Johns Episcopal Church occupied the site.

1882.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1) Washington Street, east side, between Johnson Street and Myrtle Ave. A view of the "Commonwealth Hall" at No. 323-327 Washington Street. The segment of a building No. 319, visible at left, housed the (Central Post Office) of the City of Brooklyn until 1892, when it was removed to the Federal Building, white structure, shadowing the view at the extreme left. 1909.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) The same, "16" years later, showing the center building occupied by the post office of the City of Brooklyn until 1892, which is partially seen in view No. 1. The building to the left, No. 315 Washington Street, was occupied at one time (1880-?) by the police department of the City of Brooklyn. The 4-story building at right, remodeled was the "Commonwealth House" in view No. 1.

March 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Washington Street, at the N.W. corner of Johnson Street. The view shows the old Hotel Clarendon, razed in 1936, to make way for the new approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

1,2

Washington Street, at the S. E. corner of Johnson Street, showing the Brooklyn Eagle Building; also a portion of the United States Post Office, at the N. E. corner. The view is across a new plaza, built by the W. P. A., which replaced many old rookeries.
View 2 shows the building and a wider view of the surrounding area, as seen across the Fulton Street "El." Beyond the old rookeries (right) is the Brooklyn Edison Building, and to the left of the Brooklyn Eagle Building is No. 1 Hanson Place, the Williamsburg Savings Bank Building.

December 16, 1936
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

(3)

The entrance to the Brooklyn Eagle Building, on the corner of Washington and Johnson Streets.

June 6, 1933

P. L. Sperr

Washington Street, south from, but not including Johnson Street. The view shows the Court Street Station of the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit, Fulton Street Elevated Lines. In the background, is also shown the Tower of the Borough Hall Building, and the upper half of the Brooklyn Municipal Building.

June 6, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Washington Street, east side, from Johnson (right) to Tillary Streets, showing the United States Post Office. In the foreground are construction operations by the W.P.A. on a new plaza and approach to the Brooklyn Bridge, seen from the Fulton Street "El." The plaza area was occupied by numerous rookeries and business buildings, including the Hotel Clarendon.

November 13, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(2)

The same, another view.

December 16, 1936

P. L. Sperr

(2)

December 16, 1936

P. L. Sperr

Washington Street (right), north from Johnson Street, showing the area, extending west to Liberty and Fulton Streets, which has been cleared for the construction of a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge and necessitated the razing of many buildings. In the lower right hand corner is part of the United States Post Office; to its left are elevated car yards of the B. M. T. system and the Fulton Street "El." In the background is the Manhattan Bridge and to its left a portion of the Brooklyn Bridge. Across the East River is the midtown Manhattan skyline.

Summer, 1936
Views 1,2,3

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

1,2

Washington Street (right) north from near Fulton Street, showing the area where numerous buildings are being razed, between Washington and Fulton Streets, to make way for a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. The Fulton Street "El" is on the left and the elevated car yards are in the background, at Tillary Street; on the right is the United States Post Office at Johnson Street.

View 1: March 5, 1936
View 2: March 20, 1936
